content.title: Unfractionated Heparin Pharmacology for Vascular Surgery

statement.text: Unfractionated heparin (UFH) is the cornerstone anticoagulant for vascular procedures, providing rapidly titratable anticoagulation via antithrombin III activation, monitored by PTT and reversible with protamine.
statement.formal: Mechanism: Potentiates antithrombin III; Monitoring: PTT or ACT; Reversal: Protamine (1 mg per 100 units heparin); Half-life: 60-90 minutes IV

explanation.intuition: Heparin is like a turbocharger for the body's natural anticoagulant (antithrombin III), making it work 1000 times faster. It works immediately when given IV and can be quickly reversed with protamine.
explanation.key_insight: Heparin's short half-life and protamine reversibility make it ideal for intraoperative use - full anticoagulation for the procedure, rapid offset when done.
explanation.technical_details: Unfractionated heparin binds to antithrombin III, causing a conformational change that accelerates its inhibition of thrombin (factor IIa) and factor Xa by 1000-fold. UFH is a heterogeneous mixture of molecules (MW 3000-30,000) extracted from porcine intestinal mucosa. Intravenous administration provides immediate anticoagulation. PTT is used for therapeutic monitoring (goal 60-80 seconds or 1.5-2.5x baseline). Activated clotting time (ACT) is used intraoperatively (goal >250-300 seconds). Protamine reverses heparin by ionic binding.
common_misconceptions: PTT always reflects heparin effect - FALSE, many factors affect PTT
Fixed heparin doses are adequate - FALSE, wide variability in response
Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia is always severe - FALSE, Type I is benign
Protamine has no risks - FALSE, can cause hypotension, anaphylaxis

dosing.adjustment: Based on PTT every 6 hours until stable

reversal.dose: 1 mg protamine per 100 units heparin given

definition.@value: Anticoagulant that potentiates antithrombin III to inhibit thrombin and factor Xa, used for intraoperative and therapeutic anticoagulation.

presentation: Patient requiring anticoagulation for vascular procedure

learning_objectives: Explain the mechanism of heparin anticoagulation
Calculate appropriate heparin dosing for vascular surgery
clinical_pearls: Heparin dose: 80-100 units/kg for vascular procedures, goal ACT >250
Protamine: 1 mg per 100 units heparin (give slowly to avoid hypotension)
HIT Type II: Days 5-10, immune-mediated, thrombotic - STOP heparin
Half-life 60-90 min - useful for short procedures without reversal
Check PTT or ACT before redosing intraoperatively
